title: When will Nasser Zefzafi be released from prison?
preds:
Rabat – For what could be the umpteenth time, on Tuesday the Casablanca Appeal Court postponed the trial of Nasser Zefzafi and 53 other activists involved in the Hirak Rif protests in Al Hoceima to December 19, after the defense called for the nullity of police statements “extorted under duress.”
https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2017/12/236252/hirak-trial-extorted-duress-rif-al-hoceima/
wish i never touched this one.

Zefzafis attorney accuses president of the Tangier-Tétouan-Al Hoceima region, of promoting protests:
https://africareportonbusiness.com/2017/11/22/zefzafis-lawyer-accuses-ilyas-el-omari-of-conspiring-against-morocco-and-king-mohammed-vi/

The King has been very savvy about making changes and concessions that have just enough substance that they appease and mollify the public, so I've been considering whether or not he'd pardon Zefzafi (or quietly cause the charges against him to be dropped).   We all know how hard it is to forgive those who do not acknowledge their error and who show no intention of changing.  Zefzafi appears to be one such person.  Zefzafi is being very mouthy and disruptive in court.  His behavior has caused his case to be postponed several times.  He shows no meekness, no humbleness, no fear of the system, no regret.  If released, I would expect him to be twice as disruptive and annoying.  So, I don't see the King intervening on his behalf.  I expect him to be found guilty and be given a sentence measured in  years.

He is currently on trial: http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/morocco-protest-leader-goes-on-trial-20171024#cxrecs_s But the trial has been adjourned until 31 October: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-morocco-king/moroccos-king-fires-ministers-over-slow-progress-in-restive-tribal-area-idUSKBN1CT2V7 My instinct is to think that the people pardoned by the King earlier will be the extent of leniency. If the proceedings against Zefzafi have gotten this far, the state will not drop the case or acquit on all charges.

He has some kind of hearing on the 23rd of October: https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=https://www.h24info.ma/maroc/politique/hirak-proces-de-nasser-zefzafi-prevu-23-octobre-prochain/&prev=search I don't think it means that any progress is being made. Revisit after 23 October.

Human Rights Watch has also reported on allegations of violence during the arrest of a Hirak leader, Nasser Zefzafi, who is in detention awaiting trial in Casablanca; the excessive force used to disperse a peaceful sit-in in Rabat in support of the Hirak; and the jailing of a prominent journalist after he criticized the ban on the July 20 protest.

On July 29, the eve of Throne Day, King Mohammed VI pardoned 1,178 prisoners, including 42 members of the Hirak movement, but they did not include the group sentenced by the Al Hoceima Court or those the forensic doctors had examined.

real data  https://www.deathpenaltyworldwide.org/country-search-post.cfm?country=Morocco
Country Details
Language(s)
Arabic. [1] Population
34,859,364. Western Sahara 385,000. (Jul. 2009 est.) [2] Number of Individuals Currently Under Sentence of Death
At least 104. According to the Ministry of Justice, there were 125 prisoners on death row in December 2007. [3] In 2008, at least 4 persons were sentenced to death, [4] in 2009, 13 persons were sentenced to death, [5] and in 2010, 4 persons were sentenced to death. [6] The king commuted 14 death sentences in 2008, [7] and 32 death sentences in 2009. [8] There were four death sentences and no executions in 2010. [9] This brings the total to 104.  However, the Moroccan Human Rights Organization (OMDH) and the International Federation for Human Rights (FIDH) reported a higher number of death row inmates – 133 – in late 2007/early 2008. [10] The total number of death-sentenced persons in Morocco could therefore be as high as 112. Annual Number of Reported Executions
Executions in 2017 to date ZERO (last updated on August 29, 2017) Legal status  " BBC Monitoring BC Monitoring Middle East - Political 
Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring
August 24, 2017 Thursday
"An investigation judge in the appeal court in the Moroccan city of Casablanca set the charges against 32 activists from the social protest [Hirak] movement in the northern Rif region, including conspiracy, a crime that can carry the death sentence, a member of their defence team has said, according to the news website Lakome. The judge referred the cases of Hirak movement activists to the Casablanca criminal court, their lawyer Mohamed Aghnaj said, Lakome reported on its Facebook page on 24 August. Aghnaj told Lakome that 31 of the activists, including the leader of the Hirak movement Nasser Zefzafi, are held in pre-trial detention in Okasha prison in Casablanca and one activist is free. Some of the detainees face "serious" charges, including conspiracy, and will be prosecuted in accordance with chapter 201 of Morocco's criminal code, he added. The Public Prosecutor in Casablanca Hassan Matar had called for Zefzafi and his companions to be tried in accordance with a clause in the penal code that carries the death sentence. The clause applies to anyone who carries out an attack with the aim of either provoking civil war or causing vandalism or looting. Zefzafi was arrested on 29 May. The Hirak movement has been demanding jobs and economic development in the impoverished Rif region. Unrest erupted in the region in October 2016, after a fishmonger was crushed to death in a rubbish lorry while protesting about the confiscation of his fish." Source: Facebook in Arabic 24 Aug 17 and the activists and Macron are involved  New York Times  involvement. See latest Morocco's Refusal to Listen Sept 1. 2017 www.nytimes.com from behind paywall.

From behind paywall: telling King to let Mr.  Nasser out of jail in diplo-speak France has a big role to play
"See lists of Moroccan personalities in France in 2017
Mr Salaheddine MEZOUAR, Minister for Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (7 April, 18 May, 3 June and 8 September)
Ms Hakima EL HAITE, Minister for the Environment (10 June, 8 September)
As the French government notes on this website http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/dossiers-pays/maroc/la-france-et-le-maroc/
France is Morocco's leading economic partner, despite increased competition in trade and investment. French exports to Morocco increased by nearly 20% in 2016, with a strong increase in agricultural and transport equipment. Moroccan exports to France are concentrated on textile products, electrical and electronic components and agri-food products.
France maintains its rank of first foreign investor in Morocco. France achieved in 2015 17% (484 M EUR) of the total net flow of FDI received by the Kingdom, largely concentrated in the industry. With about 750 subsidiaries of French companies listed, Morocco is the first destination of French investments on the African continent. It should be noted that 34 of the 40 CAC 40 companies are present in Morocco.
Cultural, Scientific and Technical Cooperation
Our cooperation is in line with the priorities defined by the Inter-ministerial Committee for International Cooperation and Development (CICID) and the guidelines established at the high-level meetings between Heads of Government. A Partnership Agreement for Cultural Cooperation and Development was signed on 25 July 2003 between the Prime Ministers and entered into force in March 2010.
In the field of education, the thirty-nine French institutions in Morocco (including twenty-three institutions of the Agency for French Teaching Abroad) receive 35,500 pupils, 65% of them Moroccans. The French Institute of Morocco has twelve sites (Agadir, Casablanca, Fez, Marrakech, Meknes, Oujda, Rabat, Kenitra, Tangier, Tetouan, El Jadida, Essaouira), Alliance Française the Rabat IF, thus ensuring an active and notable presence in the country. The 34,000 Moroccan students constitute the first contingent of foreign students in France.
The State visit of April 2013 paved the way for new partnership agreements between French and Moroccan higher education institutions. The most emblematic project is the creation in Fez of a Euro-Mediterranean INSA, backed by the Euro-Mediterranean University of Fez (UEMF), labeled "Union for the Mediterranean". Other projects include a School of Architecture at the International University of Rabat with the School of Architecture of Nancy, PRES-Paris East, which hosted its first promotion in October 2013, a Central School in Casablanca, Mediterranean Institute of Logistics and Transport in Tangier in partnership with the University of Valenciennes and the Ecole Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées, an international IUT, a faculty of medicine within the University of Agadir,
The French language enjoys the status of a true second language in Morocco. Our support for the teaching of French, which favors the training of trainers and the opening of international chapters, aims to consolidate this position.
The AFD group has been active in Morocco since 1992. The French Development Agency works through its Proparco subsidiary, dedicated to private sector financing, the Marseille-based Center for Financial, Economic and Banking Studies (CEFEB), the French Fund for the Global Environment Facility (FFEM), for which AFD provides the secretariat. Morocco is the first beneficiary of the French Development Agency's assistance with an exhibition of 2.5 billion euros. AFD focuses mainly on the water, environment and socio-economic infrastructure sectors. It also seeks to support the private sector, in particular by helping to modernize small and medium-sized enterprises."Updated: 03.05.17 at http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/dossiers-pays/maroc/la-france-et-le-maroc/ ..... she has emerged as one of the faces of the protest movement, singing about the death of Mouhcine Fikri, the fisherman who lost his life. Al Jazeera spoke with Ziani, who left her life as a college student to participate in the movement's activities full-time, about the prospects for the future of Morocco. Al Jazeera: What made you join the protest movement?Salima Ziani: When Mouhcine Fikri died, I felt a strong need to express my sadness. I demonstrated to speak up for myself. That horrible way in which he died allowed us to all speak up, to express our wounds. My heart was bleeding over how he was crushed in a garbage compactor. Fikri allowed us to come together as people of the Rif. We were already oppressed, but his death was our last straw. I always sang about social justice, about victims of oppression, but we were deeply saddened that the son of our land was killed in that manner. Everyone was crying - men and women were crying - as we realised that a human life had no value. But with al-Hirak al-Shaabi, we became like a big family. That is when people started knowing me; I also came up with slogans and expressed myself as a citizen. People started to know me quickly because of the strength of my voice. I wanted to show that women also were involved. I decided to stop studying and to join my brothers, who were protesting to the point that my family started missing me. I never felt that I was doing something wrong. I was just asking for justice as what is best for the country. Al Jazeera: How do you feel about the way the government has handled the protests?Ziani: We are all very peaceful. What they don't understand is that the reason we took to the street is because we love our nation, not just the Rif. We are indeed oppressed, we are indeed lacking a lot of infrastructure. I was protesting with good intentions. I never thought I would get arrested. The Moroccan constitution guarantees freedom of speech. What did I say to deserve being detained? It is our right to speak up. Al Jazeera: Can you tell us how you were detained?Ziani: I was arrested in June, a week after Nasser Zefzafi, the movement's leader, was detained. I was with two of my friends in a taxi when two cars were blocking the road. Men in plain-clothes appeared from the vehicles and took me with them. They didn't say they were with the police and they used bad language. When I saw the police station, I was relieved to find out that it was, in fact, the police. The way they treated me was harsh and I decided to accept it. I did not talk and did not answer back. They were so angry with me, I felt like I was in the hands of an enemy. They put me in a truck and took me to Casablanca. The drive was overnight and lasted about 13 hours. Meanwhile, my family was looking for me. They were told that I wasn't in police custody. Finally, in Casablanca, they put my dad on the phone. It was the first time I ever heard him crying. He told me, "You are a hero, stop crying." I spent the first night in solitary. I had a very bad reaction, so they moved me to a cell with three other inmates. During those two months, I would sometimes sing alone. If it weren't for my lawyers' visits, I would have gone crazy. IN PICTURES: Social unrest boils over in Morocco's al-Hoceima Al Jazeera: How did you feel when you were released?Ziani: I discovered many things in prison. It was one of the best experiences and one of the hardest at the same time. Before my release, the prison warden asked me to sing for the other prisoners, so I sang all kinds of musical genres. That night, I was told that I was going to be released, and in the morning, I realised that I was being released alone, without my [fellow detainees] who were still in prison.  Al Jazeera: Is al-Hirak al-Shaabi over? If not, are you still going to be a part of it?Ziani: No, it's not over, and it's because we love our country - we're going to fight for our nation. If something hurts us, we will speak up. Right now, I am healing my wounds. My brothers tell me that I made sacrifices that even men didn't make. I was abused and my message was heard. It is time for me to take some time off [from being on the front lines of the protest movement]. We demand that they release all prisoners, because ultimately, they didn't do anything wrong. It is for the interest of the region and the nation to release them. These people took to the streets not because they had nothing better to do; we protested because we are oppressed and we want to live in dignity. As citizens, we lost faith in political parties. The king inaugurates projects and nothing else happens. Many of the protesters have degrees and no jobs. Everyone lives from fishmongering here - that's all we have. During our months of protesting, we used flowers, candles, and created human chains to protect the police station, to protect the police. We are not separatists. Rif residents are peaceful people who love the king. Right now, my healing process is under way. I stopped the anti-depressants and sleeping pills that I was given in prison. I am not sleeping more than a couple of hours a night. I participated to help create something beautiful that will benefit the nation. I was very strong, but now I am tired. But in my heart, I remain very strong. Morocco's Rif activists 'fighting for our nation'" Al Jazeera - English
August 28, 2017 Monday 12:05 PM GMT Copyright 2017 Al Jazeera Media Network All Rights Reserved France is on the move His son, Prince Hassan, beside him, the king of Morocco, Mohammed VI , black glasses on his nose, goes up the red carpet to welcome Emmanuel Macron and his wife at the foot of the Falcon presidential. Neither ministers nor business leaders, the French delegation is restricted to a handful of personalities. Princess Lalla Salma, the king's wife, embraces Brigitte Macron. Beginning of a private visit, tinted with a strong "personal dimension", according to the Elysee.

And all the more important that Rabat experienced "a little disappointment" during the campaign. "Moroccans have been worried about Emmanuel Macron's visit to Algeria. They want balance to be restored, "says Pierre Vermeren, professor of contemporary Maghreb history at Paris-I University. A sign that Paris wants to maintain a balance between rival neighbors, Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian was in Algeria on Tuesday.

But "the King of Morocco has always wanted to be the first to see the elected French head of state," says Khadija Mohsen-Finan, a political scientist specializing in the Maghreb. Here is the honored monarch of the second bilateral visit of Emmanuel Macron, after Berlin. And the French president of an invitation "privileged character", according to its terms. MACRON
 thank the King for his warm welcome, I am very touched by his mark of friendship and the very personal character of the relationship that has been established between us," the French president told a press briefing of this semi-private half-official visit.

"I reaffirmed France's will to accompany the reforms carried out by the King, such as the modernization of institutions, social and territorial development, programs to combat inequalities and integration of Morocco in globalization, he said.

During the meeting, the two men also noted their convergence of views on the crisis in Qatar, each pursuing its efforts to find a diplomatic solution and to ease the tensions.

In particular, the French president intends to meet in Paris a senior official of the United Arab Emirates. He also assured that Mohammed VI was "concerned about the situation in the Rif, the northern region of the kingdom that has been a prey to popular protest for months.

NYT all over  this  See Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
AFRICA
By AIDA ALAMI AUG. 26, 2017
Thousands of people demonstrated in Al Hoceima, Morocco, last month to protest a fishmonger’s
death, as well as government corruption and the neglect of infrastructure in the Rif region.
Guillaume Pinon/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
AL HOCEIMA, Morocco — The house, down a dusty dirt track in a small
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
village near the city of Al Hoceima in northern Morocco, looked dreary
outside, with its unpainted facade, but inside the mood was cheery. Friends
and family were celebrating the return of a young singer and human rights
activist who had just been released from jail.
King Mohammed VI pardoned the young woman, Salima Ziani, 23, late last
month after his annual speech commemorating his ascension to the throne,
which is usually followed by mass pardons.
Ms. Ziani had been eating dinner with her three cellmates in Oukacha
Prison in Casablanca when she was summoned to the office of the prison
warden. The warden gave her a flower and said she was free to return to her
hometown, Al Hoceima, in the mountainous Rif region along Morocco’s
northern coast.
She had been jailed for two months for her role in leading the protests that
have been shaking the Rif since the gruesome death of a fishmonger in
October. What began as a spontaneous movement calling for a serious
inquiry into the tragedy has turned into one of the longest protest
movements in the region since the Arab Spring.
The protesters are seeking to draw attention to government corruption, as
well as to the neglect of infrastructure and economic development in the
region. Nasser Zefzafi, the leader of the group organizing the protests —
known as Hirak Chaabi, or the Popular Movement — has been in jail since
late May.
Ms. Ziani’s joy at her release was quickly tempered by the thought of so
many fellow protesters still in prison.
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
“I felt so much happiness, I thought that the Rif was going to go back to
normal,” she said in a recent interview.
But she added: “I felt so sad that the boys weren’t released. One of the
reasons we had been protesting all these months was because we wanted all
our brothers who were unjustly arrested to walk free.”
When the Arab Spring protests toppled leaders in Tunisia and Egypt in 2011,
Moroccans also took to the streets. In response, the king pushed for
constitutional reforms and ceded some power to the Parliament. The
country also enshrined Tamazight, the local Berber tongue, as an official
state language in its Constitution.
As a result of those relatively modest changes, Morocco had been mostly
stable, even while uprising convulsed many countries in the region. But the
death of the fishmonger, Mouhcine Fikri, jarred the status quo.
Mr. Fikri, 31, was crushed in a garbage compactor as he tried to retrieve his
catch, which was confiscated by the police because it contained swordfish
A protester rested during a demonstration last month in Al Hoceima. Therese Di Campo/Associated Press
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
that was caught illegally out of season. His death galvanized a public deeply
resentful of officials who are seen as heartless, corrupt and ruling over a
stagnant economy.
The Moroccan government came down hard on the protesters, arresting
more than 200, and Human Rights Watch said it had received 43
complaints of torture by the police.
“This is a serious deterioration of the human rights climate in Morocco,”
said Ahmed Benchemsi, the Morocco representative for Human Rights
Watch. “Episodic cases of police abuse and a crackdown on peaceful protests
have been documented in the recent past, but not in such a large scale in
many years.”
A demonstrator kicking at tear gas during the protest. The police injured a demonstrator who fell into a coma and died a
few weeks later. 
Al Hoceima, the cultural capital of the Rif, has long had tense relations with
the monarchy. The Berber population in the region waged war against
Spain, then Morocco’s colonial ruler, in the 1920s, defeating the Spanish
Army and declaring the Rif Republic, which lasted from 1923 to 1926.
“The republic never received international recognition,” said Hisham Aidi, a
lecturer at the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia
University, who recently published an autobiographical essay on cultural
memory in northern Morocco. “Spanish and French forces would crush the
fledgling state in 1926.”
But the rise and fall of the Rif Republic, the only Berber state in modern
history, are “seared in the region’s memory,” Mr. Aidi said.
A few years after Morocco gained its independence from France in 1956,
Crown Prince Hassan — the current monarch’s father, who would become
King Hassan II in 1961 — violently crushed a rebellion in the Rif.
For decades after that, the central government ignored the region, and tens
of thousands of mostly young people left to pursue a better life in Europe
and elsewhere.
After succeeding his father in 1999, King Mohammed introduced a policy of
reconciliation with the Rif, pushing for economic development projects,
including tourism, to try to lift the region out of poverty.
But that plan never went far, and the eastern part of the Rif has remained
economically marginalized, with no industry or universities and an economy
that relies heavily on remittances from abroad and cannabis cultivation, Mr.
Aidi said. Moroccan officials could address those needs better, he said,
rather than resorting to repressive tactics.
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong 
“The Moroccan regime’s response has been disproportionate,” he said.
“Clamping down on peaceful protesters, imprisoning young bloggers and
artists, will only harden Riffian nationalism.”
The Moroccan Interior Ministry declined to comment about the accusations
of torture and repression of peaceful protesters, and the government’s
spokesman did not return requests for comment.
During his speech in July, King Mohammed blamed political parties for the
Rif unrest, but he did not offer specific solutions to the grievances of the
area’s residents.
“If the king of Morocco is not convinced by the way political activity is
conducted, and if he does not trust a number of politicians, what are the
citizens left with?” he said.
A candlelight vigil in Casablanca this month for the protester who died. Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
In July, the police used tear gas to disperse a protest in Al Hoceima, injuring
a demonstrator who fell into a coma and later died.
Currently, police blockades surround the city and protests are banned.
Police trucks and uniformed officers have taken the place of the carousels,
concerts and street entertainments that typically fill Moroccan cities during
the summer months. Black flags mark the houses of those jailed during last
month’s protests.
On Tuesdays, families of the prisoners held in Casablanca gather at night in
front of the bus that takes them to the jailhouse 11 hours away for visits.
Rachida Kaddouri, 46, a civil servant, has been going to Casablanca every
week, sometimes taking her two daughters with her. Her husband,
Mohamed Mejjaoui, a teacher, who was arrested in late May, is considered
to be one of the leaders of the Hirak movement.
Ms. Kaddouri said the solidarity among the prisoners’ families was helping
A protest in June in Al Hoceima. What began as a spontaneous movement calling for a serious inquiry into a fishmonger’s
death has turned into one of the longest protest movements in the region since the Arab Spring.
Fadel Senna/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
Morocco’s Stability Is Roiled by Monthslong Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/world/africa/morocco-berber-rif-nasser-zefzafi.html[8/27/2017 9:01:37 PM]
her through the hardship.
“What is most important is that my husband is released,” she said. “He
didn’t do anything wrong. He only defended the rights of his countrymen.
They could also at least transfer them to a jail closer to us.”
Some of the demands of the July protesters have been met. An oncology unit
was opened in Al Hoceima, and the government agreed to hire more civil
servants. But many believe that the high level of repression will only amplify
the unrest.
Omghar Fikri, a civil servant and a volunteer who helps the families of
prisoners organize their weekly visits, believes there is space for
compromise.
“We have to create a conversation,” said Mr. Fikri, who is not related to
Mouhcine Fikri, the fish seller. “One of the deepest roots of the Hirak
movement was the bad relationship with the state. There is a political
apathy and a complete loss of trust in politicians. And these problems need
to be fixed.”
Ms. Ziani, the released prisoner, who is most commonly known by her artist
and Berber name, Silya, has always been a vocal human rights activist. She
quit college in October to engage in demonstrations full time, and she has
written numerous songs about Mouhcine Fikri and the protests.
“When I wrote the songs, I cried,” she said. “I expressed myself through my
songs. That was my way of expressing my anger.”:
A version of this article appears in print on August 27, 2017, on Page A15 of the New York edition
 Morocco Roiled by Months long Protests Over Fishmonger’s Death - The New York Times

See geneally French  Military Rule in Morocco: Colonialism and its Consequences, by Moshe Gershovich. London and Portland, OR: Frank Cass Publishers, 2000. x By Porch, Douglas W Moshe Gershovich from Middle East Journal © 
. “France's relationship with its Moroccan Protectorate (1912-25) has generally been regarded as a happy one, especially when compared with that of neighboring Algeria, for at least three reasons. First, France's Moroccan policies were skillfully guided by the flamboyant Resident General Hubert Lyautey, whose patient "oil-spot" strategy of conquest and "indirect" methods of governing both avoided a bloody and divisive conquest and preserved much of Morocco's traditional political structure. Second, Moroccan soldiers acquired a reputation for ferocity and loyalty in two world wars that made them the Gurkas of the French army. Lastly, unlike Indochina and Algeria, the French retained the good sense to depart Morocco before they became totally engulfed in the tide of Moroccan nationalism, leaving behind a conservative government well-disposed to France. Moshe Gershovich amplifies this vision of a Franco-Moroccan past. He argues that Lyautey was essentially a pragmatist whose policies were forced on him by opponents of colonial expansion in Paris, by a dearth of soldiers available to complete the conquest, and by his growing conviction that Moroccan independence was inevitable. French Military Rule in Morocco: Colonialism and Its Consequences” And I believe that Morocco is, much like Jordan, a staunch US and EU ally and  France that great and ancient civilization has much more of a role  in Morocco.

Rabat – Nasser Zafzafi, the detained leading activist of the Hirak protest movement in Rif region, has been transferred to the headquarters of the National Brigade of Judiciary Police (BNPJ), lawyer Khadija Rougani, a member of the activist’s defense team, has announced. The lawyer said that Zafzafi’s transfer to the BNPJ’s headquarters is probably related to a letter attributed to Zafzafi that was published by media on Thursday. “To this point, it is not clear why he is under interrogation. The reason could mostly be the letter that circulated,” Rougani said in a statement to Lakome2. Zafzafi has been under detentions in Oukacha Prision in Casablanca. He and dozens of other activists held in Casablanca and Al Hoceima are accused of several heavy crimes including “undermining the security” of the country. On Thursday, online media outlets published a letter attributed to Zafzafi urging the population of Al Hoceima to preserve in their endeavors until their “legitimate demands” are answered. He also warned his follow protesters against violence, calling such actions a betrayal of the movement’s peaceful principles. “He who throws a stone has betrayed Hirak and the detainees, and he who breaks a glass is not [a member] of Hirak,” reads the letter. The General Directorate of the Prison and Reintegration Administration (DGAPR) released a statement later on denying the letter was written by Zafzafi, even though Mohammed Ziane, another member of his defense team, said the letter was indeed written by his client.

http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/morocco-court-orders-protest-leader-to-stand-trial/893243 "A Casablanca court has ended investigations into a number of activists arrested three months ago for taking part in anti-government protests in Morocco’s northern Al-Rif region, according to a local legal source. "Late Wednesday, the court ordered protest leader Nasser Zefzafi -- and six other activists -- to stand trial on charges of “harming the integrity of the state”, defense lawyer Mohamed Aghnaj told Anadolu Agency. "According to Aghnaj, a date for the trial will be announced at some point later this week. "For the last 10 months, Morocco’s northern Al-Rif region -- especially the city of Al-Hoceima -- has been rocked by protests by local youth demanding jobs and an end of perceived government corruption. "On several occasions, the demonstrations have been forcibly dispersed by security forces, leading to a number of injuries -- and at least one death -- among protesters. "Demonstrations first erupted last October when a local fisherman, Mohsen Fikri, was crushed to death by a garbage truck in Al-Hoceima while protesting attempts by police to confiscate his fish. "Since then, at least 250 people have been arrested for taking part in the demonstrations, dozens of whom remain in police custody.

The country is essentially operated as a hybrid of a monarchy and dictatorship.  The government charges he is undermining the security of the state. I do not know this situation very well but Muhammad VI is getting less reform-minded as he stays in power and the economy is good enough to breed complacency (http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/morocco/overview) in my opinion.  Western countries seem tired of problems in "Africa" and won't apply much pressure to a relatively minor player on that continental board.  Mr. Zefzahi also has a small audience (small country population in a big country in city far from the capital) and has no logs in his fire to keep it going, just kindling and newspaper scraps.

The response of the Moroccan government to unrest, be it in Rif or Western Sahara, consists mainly of cracking down and arresting people. They currently hold a number of political prisoners from both regions and the government doesn't show signs of changing course, especially not in the next five months.
five months is not a long time to hold someone.
